newsitem.title: FRANCE: Bus drivers strike hits French cities for 14th day.
newsitem.headline: Bus drivers strike hits French cities for 14th day.

text.p: A stoppage by bus drivers gripped several French provincial cities on Wednesday for the 14th successive day in the latest labour challenge to the government of Prime Minister Alain Juppe.

In the south-western city of Toulouse, a bastion of the stoppages where drivers have been on strike for 24 days, about half the usual buses were running, staffed by non-striking drivers under police protection for a third day in a row.
The strike, for shorter working hours and early retirement, continued to hit transport in Cannes, Nice, Le Mans, Clermont-Ferrand and Sete.
On Tuesday, buses had got back to normal in the Mediterranean port of Toulon and in the north-eastern city of Lille after drivers accepted a management offer of shorter hours.

The nationwide stoppages, inspired by Toulouse, began 14 days ago in 20 provincial cities with unions seeking a cut in working hours to 35 hours from 39 with no pay cut, and retirement at 55 years rather than at 60.
Transport companies have given ground on working hours but less on early retirement. Juppe last year bowed to truckers' demands for retirement at 55 after they blocked roads.
